P.title: By 2050, will there be fewer than 400 public 4-year colleges in the US?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there are fewer than 400 public 4-year colleges in the US in any year after 2018, up to and including the 2049-2050 school term, according to NCES. If NCES no longer reports this data, other credible sources may be used. If the school year is no longer over a similar period, the final term can be any period which ends in 2050

para_P.title: Will the number of public four-year universities in the United States drop below 400 by the year 2050?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be considered resolved as 'Yes' if, at any point from 2019 onwards until the end of the 2049-2050 academic year, the count of public four-year universities in the U.S. falls below 400, as reported by the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) or another reliable source if NCES does not provide this data. If the academic calendar changes, the relevant term is any that concludes in 2050.

metadata.background_info:
The skyrocketing cost of college education in the the United States has led many to speculate on how costs can be brought under control or if they'll continue to rise. Neuroscientist and fiction author Erik Hoel wrote the following about college education in the year 2050 in a blog post published August 25, 2021
The education bubble will have popped and in 2050 the majority of education will take place online. A combination of private tutors and MOOCs and testing centers will have become the most common form of education. Students will compile credits from these different courses for different degrees. Colleges and universities will have lost much of their prestige and most mid-tier institutions will be closed or closing.
According to the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) there were 768 public 4 year colleges in the US in the 2018-2019 school year. If this number fell under 400 by 2050, that would be a drop of 48%.

P.title: Will alien technosignatures be detected before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a competent and credible authority on astronomy and or space exploration (such as NASA, ESA, ROSCOSMOS, CNSA, JAXA, SETI or similar) announces that, on the balance of probabilities (i.e. more than 50% likely), technosignatures of non-human origin have been discovered before January 1, 2050. This announcement qualifies only if it is made after a year waiting period following the initial announcement of the detection, unless the space agencies of the US, Russia, China and Europe all agree that the finding is genuine. Evidence of biosignatures alone will not be directly relevant to the resolution of this question.
By 'non-human origin,' this question refers to technosignatures that are not the result of human activity, or of the activity of any technology or 'lifeform' created by humans, including any artificial intelligence system or biological organism

Such confirmation must follow a one-year verification period post the initial discovery announcement, unless there is unanimous agreement on the authenticity of the discovery by the major space agencies of the US, Russia, China, and Europe. The presence of biosignatures, however, will not influence the outcome of this question.
By 'not originating from humans,' it is meant that the technosignatures are not produced by human actions, any human-made technology, or any life forms engineered by humans, including any artificial intelligence or biological entities.

P.title: Will Apollo 10's Lunar Module be recovered by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Lunar Module flown on Apollo 10 is the only flown lunar module which didn't end up crashing into the Moon or burning up in Earth's atmosphere.
After 'dress rehearsal' testing in lunar orbit, during which the Lunar Module came within 8.4 nautical miles of the lunar surface, the ascent engine performed a burn to depletion which sent the craft into interplanetary space and the vehicle is currently in a heliocentric orbit. The location of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module is unknown as of May 2019, but efforts are underway to find it.
As a unique historical artefact from the original golden age of human spaceflight, this Lunar Module would certainly make for an interesting museum exhibit.
This question asks: by 1 January 2050, will the lost ascent stage of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module be recovered (i.e. located, captured, and physically transported to some location where humans have a presence at that time, such as Earth, the Moon, Mars or elsewhere) successfully?

para_P.title: By 2050, will the Apollo 10 Lunar Module ascent stage be retrieved?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Apollo 10 Lunar Module, the only one that did not crash on the Moon or disintegrate in Earth's atmosphere, underwent a critical test in lunar orbit. It approached the Moon's surface to within 8.4 nautical miles before its ascent engine was depleted, propelling it into a heliocentric orbit. As of May 2019, its exact location remains undetermined, though search efforts are ongoing.
This module, a significant relic from the pioneering era of space exploration, would be a valuable addition to any space history collection.
The question is: by the start of 2050, will the missing ascent stage of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module be retrieved (i.e., found, secured, and transported to a human-occupied location such as Earth, the Moon, Mars, or another celestial body)?

P.title: Before 2070, Will there be a civil war in a country that, in January 2022, had a median age above 30?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Related Questions on Metaculus:
Will a civil war break out in a country with median age above 30 before 2070?
Will the USA enter a second civil war before 2031?
There is a large variation in the median age of countries. Some have suggested that a youth bulge makes civil war more likely. Syria, Afghanistan, Libya, and Iraq have median ages at most 30 and experienced civil wars recently, as does virtually all of sub-Saharan Africa which has experienced civil wars. Sri Lanka's median age passed 30 right around the time the Sri Lankan Civil War ended. Younger populations are associated with an increased risk of civil war.
Before 2070, Will there be a civil war in a country that, in January 2020, had a median age above 30?
This question will resolve positively if before January 1, 2070, at least two of the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, the Economist, the Guardian, and the Spectator indicate that a civil war begins in a country that has a median age is 30.1 or above according to the 2020 figures from both the CIA World Factbook and the United Nations.. A copy of this data is available here.
In the case of political or territorial changes of any nation on the list, the successor country will be identified as having the same political capitol as the parent country.

P.title: Will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A hemispherectomy is
a very rare neurosurgical procedure in which a cerebral hemisphere (half of the brain) is removed, disconnected, or disabled. This procedure is used to treat a variety of seizure disorders where the source of the epilepsy is localized to a broad area of a single hemisphere of the brain, notably Rasmussen's encephalitis. [...]
Because of the dramatic alteration of brain composition and the inherent risk that hemispherectomies pose, there are criteria that must be met in order for a person to qualify for the procedure. Criteria include no successful control of seizures throughout a variety of drug trials, and a reasonable to high chance of procedural success.
One such predictor of success is often the age of the patient. This procedure is almost exclusively performed in children because their brains generally display more neuroplasticity, allowing neurons from the remaining hemisphere to take over the tasks from the lost hemisphere. [...]
The success of the procedure is not, however, limited to children. A study in 2007 indicated the long-term efficacy of anatomic hemispherectomy in carefully selected adults, with seizure control sustainable over multiple decades. A case study published in 2015 of 2 adults aged 48 and 38 demonstrated the success of functional hemispherectomy in treating status epilepticus (SE), an epileptic condition in which seizures are prolonged or occur closely together. In 2012, a case study following 30 individuals having undergone some form of hemispherectomy in adulthood found that 81% of individuals were seizure free post-procedure. Furthermore, almost all participating patients reported improved quality of life. The conclusion: “adult patients do not have to expect more problems with new deficits, appear to cope quite well, and most profit from surgery in several quality of life domains.”
While hemispherectomies are generally reserved as a treatment for extreme cases of seizure disorders, they could conceivably aid in life extension as well. In particular, a patient could voluntarily receive a hemispherectomy in order to cryopreserve and put their brain in long-term storage while they are still living, thereby increasing the probability that their personality and identity are stored in some sort of medium, persisting into the future.
So far as I can tell, a hemispherectomy performed for the purpose of life extension is purely hypothetical. Furthermore, there are few to no current online resources about this possibility (besides this one).
This question asks, will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100?
Here the resolution is determined by the conjunction of three actions, performed by an individual human:
They received a hemispherectomy voluntarily.
Half of their brain was placed in long-term cryopreservation while they were still legally alive.
They reported in some credible source (such as through a media outlet, or via a forum with strong evidence of credibility) that the procedure was done primarily for the purpose of extending their life.

para_P.title: By 2100, will there be any reported cases of individuals undergoing a hemispherectomy to extend their lifespan?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A hemispherectomy is a highly specialized neurosurgical intervention where one cerebral hemisphere is either removed, disconnected, or disabled. This operation is primarily employed to manage severe seizure disorders, particularly when epileptic activity is confined to a large region of one brain hemisphere, such as in Rasmussen's encephalitis. [...]
Given the significant changes to brain structure and the associated risks, specific criteria must be satisfied for a patient to be eligible for this surgery. These criteria include unsuccessful seizure management through various pharmacological treatments and a moderate to high likelihood of surgical success.
A key factor influencing success is the patient's age, with the procedure predominantly being performed on children due to their greater neuroplasticity, which enables the remaining brain hemisphere to compensate for the functions of the removed hemisphere. [...]
The effectiveness of the surgery is not limited to children alone. Research from 2007 shows the long-term success of anatomic hemispherectomy in selected adults, maintaining seizure control for many years. A 2015 case study of two adults aged 48 and 38 demonstrated the efficacy of functional hemispherectomy in managing status epilepticus (SE), a severe epileptic condition characterized by prolonged or closely spaced seizures. A 2012 study tracking 30 adults who underwent various forms of hemispherectomy found that 81% were free of seizures after the surgery, with nearly all reporting enhanced life quality. The conclusion was that adult patients generally do not experience additional problems or deficits post-surgery, manage well, and often see improvements in several aspects of life quality.
While typically reserved for severe seizure conditions, hemispherectomies might also potentially contribute to life extension. Specifically, an individual might choose to undergo a hemispherectomy to cryopreserve their brain while still alive, potentially preserving their personality and identity for the future.
To date, the concept of a hemispherectomy for life extension remains theoretical, with limited information available online about this application (other than this one).
This question inquires whether by the year 2100, any individual will have reported undergoing a hemispherectomy with the primary goal of lifespan extension. The resolution will be confirmed if an individual has voluntarily undergone the procedure, had half of their brain cryopreserved while still legally alive, and reported through a credible source that the surgery was primarily aimed at extending their lifespan.

P.title: Will DNA testing vindicate Jeanne Calment as the oldest recorded person in history?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
To facilitate discussion, in what follows the names 'Jeanne Calment' and 'Yvonne Calment' refer to the women born in 1875 and 1898, respectively, regardless of when these women died; and the name 'Mme Calment' refers to the woman who died in 1997, regardless of when she was born.
Jeanne Calment (born 21 February 1875) was, until recently, widely considered to have died on 4 August 1997 and to be, as such, the oldest verified person in history, reaching the remarkable age of 122 years and 164 days. In 2018, Russian mathematician Nikolay Zak—prompted by Valery Novoselov, an assistant professor of gerontology and geriatrics at RUDN University in Moscow—uploaded a paper to ResearchGate, subsequently published in the journal Rejuvenation Research, challenging this view. Zak argued that the person who died in 1997 was Jeanne Calment's daughter, Yvonne Calment (born 29 January 1898), who upon Jeanne's death in 1934 assumed her official identity for tax evasion purposes.
Versions of this “identity switch hypothesis” had been advanced in the past (including by fellow Metaculites), but it was only with the publication of Zak’s paper and its popularization and further development by life-extension activist Yuri Deigin in a series of blog posts that the thesis attracted widespread attention and discussion. The main facts adduced in support of this hypothesis are, to quote from Gwern's useful summary, "the suspiciousness of the Calment family archives being destroyed by them, some anomalies in Calment’s passport, oddities in family arrangements, apparent inconsistency of Calment’s recollections & timing of events & photos, facial landmarks like ear features not seeming to match up between young/old photos, and an obscure 2007 accusation in a French book that a French bureaucrat and/or the insurance company had uncovered the fraud but the French state quietly suppressed the findings because of Calment’s national fame."
The response of the professional community of demographers has been generally skeptical. Jean-Marie Robine, a respected scholar who co-validated Calment's longevity record, was particularly critical: "You can talk with any scholar, who would say, we would not accept this even from a student. It’s not scientific, there’s no methodology, no hypothesis, no nothing." His colleague and co-author Michel Allard also criticized the study, though he noted that "even if far-fetched, the Russians’ conclusions should be given consideration." After a "rather tense" meeting of the National Institute for Demographic Studies in early 2019, longevity experts from France, Swiss and Belgium concluded that an exhumation may be needed to settle the controversy.
More recently, it has been discovered that blood samples taken from Mme Calment have been preserved by the Fondation Jean Dausset-CEPH in Paris. Furthermore, researcher Phil Gibbs and gerontologist Aubrey De Grey independently noted that, because of inbreeding, Yvonne Calment had only 12 great-great-grandparents, whereas Jeanne Calment had the usual 16. Thus, the true identity of Mme Calment could be straightforwardly established by conducting a single DNA test on a blood sample already in possession of a laboratory.
In light of this, we now ask: Conditional on relevant DNA tests being carried out, will it be shown that Mme Calment was Jeanne Calment?
Resolution
The question will resolve before the official resolution date (January 1, 2030) if and when the results of a DNA test of Mme Calment, following either an exhumation of her body or an analysis of a preserved blood sample, are officially announced. The resolution will then be determined as follows:
If the DNA of the exhumed body or the blood sample is shown to be that of someone with 12 great-great-grandparents, the question resolves negative; if it is shown the be that of someone with 16 great-great-grandparents, it resolves positive; otherwise, it resolves ambiguous.
If the official body of Yvonne Calment is also exhumed and tested, the question resolves negative if DNA testing shows Mme Calment to be Yvonne Calment, and positive otherwise.
In the unlikely event that both of the criteria above become relevant and yield inconsistent resolutions, the question will resolve according to criterion (2).
In all these cases, the question will retroactively close one week before the test results are officially announced.
If the question doesn't resolve before the official resolution date, it will resolve ambiguous.
Further reading
In addition to the writings listed above, readers may want to consult the following papers:
Zak & Gibbs, A Bayesian Assessment of the Longevity of Jeanne Calment (in favor of the ID switch hypothesis).
Robine, Allard, Herrmann & Jeune, The Real Facts Supporting Jeanne Calment as the Oldest Ever Human (against the ID switch hypothesis).

para_P.title: Will genetic analysis confirm Jeanne Calment's status as the longest-lived individual on record?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the purpose of this discussion, 'Jeanne Calment' and 'Yvonne Calment' will denote the individuals born in 1875 and 1898, respectively, irrespective of their dates of death; 'Mme Calment' will refer to the individual who passed away in 1997, regardless of her birth year.
Jeanne Calment, believed until recently to have passed on 4 August 1997 and recognized as the oldest verified human ever, having lived 122 years and 164 days, came under scrutiny in 2018. Russian mathematician Nikolay Zak, encouraged by Valery Novoselov, a gerontology and geriatrics assistant professor at RUDN University, published a paper on ResearchGate, later featured in Rejuvenation Research, disputing this claim. Zak suggested that the woman who died in 1997 was actually Jeanne Calment's daughter, Yvonne Calment, who allegedly assumed her mother's identity after her death in 1934 to avoid taxes.
This 'identity switch theory' had been previously proposed by others, but gained significant traction after Zak’s publication and subsequent promotion by Yuri Deigin through various blog posts. Key evidence supporting this theory includes the destruction of the Calment family archives, anomalies in Calment’s passport, unusual family dynamics, inconsistencies in Calment’s memories and the timing of events and photographs, differences in facial features in young and old photos, and a 2007 claim in a French book that a bureaucrat and/or an insurance company discovered the fraud but it was suppressed by the French government due to Calment’s national renown.
The demographic research community has largely been skeptical of these claims. Jean-Marie Robine, a prominent scholar who confirmed Calment's age record, was notably critical, stating that such a hypothesis would not be accepted even from a student due to its lack of scientific rigor. His colleague Michel Allard, while critical, acknowledged that the Russian findings warranted some consideration. A meeting at the National Institute for Demographic Studies in early 2019, attended by longevity experts from France, Switzerland, and Belgium, concluded that exhuming the body might be necessary to resolve the dispute.
More recently, it has been revealed that blood samples from Mme Calment are stored at the Fondation Jean Dausset-CEPH in Paris. Researchers Phil Gibbs and Aubrey De Grey noted that due to inbreeding, Yvonne Calment had only 12 great-great-grandparents, while Jeanne Calment had the standard 16. This difference could definitively identify Mme Calment through a single DNA test on the existing blood sample.
Given this, the question now is: Assuming the relevant DNA tests are conducted, will it be proven that Mme Calment was indeed Jeanne Calment?
Resolution
The question will be resolved before the set deadline (January 1, 2030) if and when DNA test results from either an exhumed body or the analyzed blood sample are officially released. The resolution will be based on the following criteria:
If the DNA from the body or blood sample indicates 12 great-great-grandparents, the question resolves negatively; if it indicates 16 great-great-grandparents, it resolves positively; otherwise, it resolves ambiguously.
If Yvonne Calment's body is also exhumed and tested, a negative resolution will occur if DNA tests identify Mme Calment as Yvonne Calment, and a positive resolution otherwise.
Should both criteria become relevant and conflict, the question will be resolved according to the second criterion.
In all scenarios, the question will close one week before the announcement of the test results.
If no resolution occurs by the deadline, the question will resolve ambiguously.
Additional Resources
For further information, readers may refer to the following publications:
Zak & Gibbs, A Bayesian Assessment of the Longevity of Jeanne Calment (supporting the ID switch hypothesis).
Robine, Allard, Herrmann & Jeune, The Real Facts Supporting Jeanne Calment as the Oldest Ever Human (opposing the ID switch hypothesis).

P.title: Will DNA testing vindicate Jeanne Calment as the oldest recorded person in history?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
To facilitate discussion, in what follows the names 'Jeanne Calment' and 'Yvonne Calment' refer to the women born in 1875 and 1898, respectively, regardless of when these women died; and the name 'Mme Calment' refers to the woman who died in 1997, regardless of when she was born.
Jeanne Calment (born 21 February 1875) was, until recently, widely considered to have died on 4 August 1997 and to be, as such, the oldest verified person in history, reaching the remarkable age of 122 years and 164 days. In 2018, Russian mathematician Nikolay Zak—prompted by Valery Novoselov, an assistant professor of gerontology and geriatrics at RUDN University in Moscow—uploaded a paper to ResearchGate, subsequently published in the journal Rejuvenation Research, challenging this view. Zak argued that the person who died in 1997 was Jeanne Calment's daughter, Yvonne Calment (born 29 January 1898), who upon Jeanne's death in 1934 assumed her official identity for tax evasion purposes.
Versions of this “identity switch hypothesis” had been advanced in the past (including by fellow Metaculites), but it was only with the publication of Zak’s paper and its popularization and further development by life-extension activist Yuri Deigin in a series of blog posts that the thesis attracted widespread attention and discussion. The main facts adduced in support of this hypothesis are, to quote from Gwern's useful summary, "the suspiciousness of the Calment family archives being destroyed by them, some anomalies in Calment’s passport, oddities in family arrangements, apparent inconsistency of Calment’s recollections & timing of events & photos, facial landmarks like ear features not seeming to match up between young/old photos, and an obscure 2007 accusation in a French book that a French bureaucrat and/or the insurance company had uncovered the fraud but the French state quietly suppressed the findings because of Calment’s national fame."
The response of the professional community of demographers has been generally skeptical. Jean-Marie Robine, a respected scholar who co-validated Calment's longevity record, was particularly critical: "You can talk with any scholar, who would say, we would not accept this even from a student. It’s not scientific, there’s no methodology, no hypothesis, no nothing." His colleague and co-author Michel Allard also criticized the study, though he noted that "even if far-fetched, the Russians’ conclusions should be given consideration." After a "rather tense" meeting of the National Institute for Demographic Studies in early 2019, longevity experts from France, Swiss and Belgium concluded that an exhumation may be needed to settle the controversy.
More recently, it has been discovered that blood samples taken from Mme Calment have been preserved by the Fondation Jean Dausset-CEPH in Paris. Furthermore, researcher Phil Gibbs and gerontologist Aubrey De Grey independently noted that, because of inbreeding, Yvonne Calment had only 12 great-great-grandparents, whereas Jeanne Calment had the usual 16. Thus, the true identity of Mme Calment could be straightforwardly established by conducting a single DNA test on a blood sample already in possession of a laboratory.
In light of this, we now ask: Conditional on relevant DNA tests being carried out, will it be shown that Mme Calment was Jeanne Calment?
Resolution
The question will resolve before the official resolution date (January 1, 2030) if and when the results of a DNA test of Mme Calment, following either an exhumation of her body or an analysis of a preserved blood sample, are officially announced. The resolution will then be determined as follows:
If the DNA of the exhumed body or the blood sample is shown to be that of someone with 12 great-great-grandparents, the question resolves negative; if it is shown the be that of someone with 16 great-great-grandparents, it resolves positive; otherwise, it resolves ambiguous.
If the official body of Yvonne Calment is also exhumed and tested, the question resolves negative if DNA testing shows Mme Calment to be Yvonne Calment, and positive otherwise.
In the unlikely event that both of the criteria above become relevant and yield inconsistent resolutions, the question will resolve according to criterion (2).
In all these cases, the question will retroactively close one week before the test results are officially announced.
If the question doesn't resolve before the official resolution date, it will resolve ambiguous.
Further reading
In addition to the writings listed above, readers may want to consult the following papers:
Zak & Gibbs, A Bayesian Assessment of the Longevity of Jeanne Calment (in favor of the ID switch hypothesis).
Robine, Allard, Herrmann & Jeune, The Real Facts Supporting Jeanne Calment as the Oldest Ever Human (against the ID switch hypothesis).
